page.title: 01Taddington Area
page.content: This area around the village of Taddington is part of the higher land in the White Peak.It consists of grassy upland with clumps of trees warning of shafts and spoil heaps from the old lead-mining activities.It was one of the smaller liberties in the King's Field.There is visual evidence of early settlement from the Neolothic Age due,perhaps,to the springs in the area.The older part of the linear village is sheltered under a north facing hill.It has one of the highest post offices and schools in England. Annual rainfall varies from 110-150cm.Despite a local saying of "nine months winter and three months bad weather" holidaymakers rent cottages throughout the year.Farms have reduced in number during the past fifty years but all the land is farmed.The population is about 425.
